input: Question: Tell me a bio of Jessie Mae Brown Beavers.
output:
Jessie Mae Brown Beavers was born on December 11, 1947, in Millport, Alabama. She is an American former politician who served as a member of the Tennessee Senate for the 17th district from 2003 to 2017. Prior to her time in the state senate, Beavers was a state representative in the 99th through the 102nd General Assemblies. In 1990, she was a member of the Brantfort Lady Blues team that won the Ontario Ladies Hockey League Championships, and she maintained a high female average and high triple score in Ontario Indian Bowling Championship in 1973. Beavers is also a professional athlete who won the most valuable player award eight times from 1962 to 1980 and was awarded the Filmmakers Hall of Fame in 1976.

Beavers' mother, Louise Beavers, was an American film and television actress who appeared in dozens of films and two hit television shows from the 1920s until 1960. Beavers was born in Cincinnati, Ohio, and was a member of Sigma Gamma Rho sorority, one of the four African-American sororities. Beavers was a breakthrough actress for black women and became known as a symbol of a "mammy" on the screen.

In conclusion, Jessie Mae Brown Beavers is a prominent figure in both politics and sports, with a successful career in both fields. Her mother, Louise Beavers, was a pioneering actress who paved the way for other black women in the entertainment industry.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Billy Conigliaro.
output:
Billy Conigliaro was born on August 15, 1947, in Revere, Massachusetts. He was a former Major League Baseball outfielder who played in the American League for the Boston Red Sox (1969-1971), Milwaukee Brewers (1972), and Oakland Athletics (1973). Conigliaro is the younger brother of Tony Conigliaro, and the two were teammates on the Red Sox in 1969 and 1970.

During his time with the Red Sox, Conigliaro showed great promise as a hitter, with 16 doubles and 18 home runs in 1970, and 26 doubles and 11 home runs in 1971. He finished 8th in the American League in doubles in 1971, which was his most productive season. However, his career was cut short when he announced his retirement from baseball in the middle of the 1972 season, unhappy with the team's management.

Conigliaro returned to baseball in 1973 as a part-time player with the Oakland Athletics, making brief appearances in the American League Championship Series and the World Series. He became disgruntled with the Athletics' ownership and retired at the conclusion of that season. Conigliaro attempted a comeback with the Athletics several years later but ultimately retired for good after being assigned to their minor league affiliate on a temporary basis.

Throughout his career, Conigliaro was known for his potential as a hitter, but his career was marred by injuries and conflicts with management. Despite his talents, he was unable to achieve the success he desired in the major leagues.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Maxime Masson.
output:
Based on the documents provided, here is a brief bio of Maxime Masson:

Maxime Masson was born on October 15, 1867, in Saint-Justin, Quebec, and was a Roman Catholic priest. He was the main architect of religious buildings in the town of Sainte-Thècle, where he served as pastor for 52 years. During his time as pastor, he coordinated the construction of the church, rectory, and other buildings on the lot of the "Fabrique de Sainte-Thècle" from 1903 to 1905. He was also instrumental in the erection of the monastery ("couvent" in French) in 1912.

Masson studied classics at Séminaire Saint-Joseph de Trois-Rivières and theology at the Grand Seminary Trois-Rivières, and was ordained as a priest on July 8, 1894, in the chapel of the Seminary Trois-Rivières. Prior to his assignment as pastor of Sainte-Thècle, he served as vicar of the parish of Saint-Justin (1894-1899), at Saint-Léon-le-Grand (1902), and at Saint-Timothée of Hérouxville (1902-1903).

In addition to his work as a priest, Masson was also the first president of the School board of the village of Sainte-Thècle from July 19, 1915, to April 14, 1947.

It is worth noting that there is also a person named Manon Massé, who is a Canadian politician in Quebec. Manon Massé was born in 1963 in Windsor, Quebec, and was elected to the National Assembly of Quebec in the 2014 election. Daniel Alexander Cameron was born on December 10, 1870, in Sydney River, Nova Scotia, Canada. His parents were John and Isabella (Macdonald) Cameron. He was educated at Sydney Academy and Dalhousie University, where he received a Bachelor of Laws degree. He was admitted to the bar in October 1893 and started practicing law in Sydney in the same year. Cameron was a member of the County Council from 1900 to 1911 and served as the stipendiary magistrate for Sydney from 1905 to 1911.

Cameron was an athlete and won many prizes at Boy Scouts sports events. In his late teens, he competed in relay races with Eric Liddell, who was famously portrayed in the movie "Chariots of Fire." Cameron was also a successful high-jumper, as his grandfather, Sandy Dees, had been the high jump champion of Scotland.

Cameron's mother was Margaret Brua, and he was commonly referred to as "Don." After leaving Princeton College (today Princeton University), where he graduated with a bachelor of arts in 1852 and received a master of arts degree in 1855, Cameron's father, Simon, placed him as a clerk at the successful Middleton Bank in Pennsylvania. Cameron worked his way up to becoming a successful businessman in the iron, coal, and lumber industries of Pennsylvania.

Cameron passed away on September 4, 1937, at the age of 66.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Margaret Rose Vendryes.
output:
Based on the documents provided, Margaret Rose Vendryes is a visual artist, curator, and art historian based in New York. She was born in Kingston, Jamaica in 1955. Vendryes began her studies in costume design before moving to fine art and earning a Bachelor's degree at Amherst College in 1984. She went on to earn her MA in Art History in 1992 from Tulane University and her PhD from Princeton University in 1997, where she focused on African American art history.

Vendryes is currently the Chair of the Department of Performing and Fine Arts and Director of the Fine Arts Gallery at York College in New York. She has curated several exhibitions, including "i found god in myself: the 40th anniversary of Ntozake Shange's for colored girls..." which traveled to the African American Museum in Philadelphia in 2016 and City Without Walls (cWOW) gallery in 2017 in Newark, New Jersey. The exhibition featured works by several artists, including Renée Cox, Carrie Mae Weems, Deborah Willis, Saya Woolfalk, Michael Paul Britto, Pamela Council, and Dianne Smith.

Vendryes' own artistic practice combines juxtapositions and combinations of portraits of Western pop culture icons with traditional African masks. She has explored themes of power, race, gender, and beauty through these works, which have included images of Black American women icons such as Aretha Franklin, Grace Jones, and Whitney Houston. In 2014, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture commissioned an artwork from Vendryes for an exhibition celebrating the 40th anniversary of Ntozake Shange's "for colored girls who have considered suicide / when the rainbow is enuf," titled "My spirit is too ancient to understand the separation."

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Patricia Cladis.
output:
Based on the documents provided, here is a brief bio of Patricia Cladis:

Patricia Cladis was a Canadian-American physicist who specialized in the physics of liquid crystals. She was born in Shanghai in 1937 and grew up in Vancouver, British Columbia. Cladis earned her B.A. in combined Honours Mathematics and Physics from the University of British Columbia in 1959, and then went on to earn her M.A. in Physics from the University of Toronto in 1960.

After completing her graduate studies, Cladis worked as a meteorologist for Transport Canada from 1960 to 1962, and then as a Programmer-Analyst at KCS Ltd. from 1962 to 1963. She was appointed as an Assistant Professor of Physics at Western Connecticut State University in 1963, where she worked for four years before moving to the University of Rochester to pursue her Ph.D. in Physics with a concentration in superconductivity. Cladis received her Ph.D. in 1968 and then spent three years in Paris as a researcher.

Throughout her career, Cladis was a prolific researcher and writer, publishing over 130 publications and editing multiple books, including "Spatio-temporal patterns in nonequilibrium complex systems" in 1995. She was a fellow of the American Physical Society and received a Guggenheim fellowship. Cladis passed away on July 3, 2017, in Summit, New Jersey.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Jimmy Tompkins (priest).
output:
Based on the provided documents, here is a bio of Jimmy Tompkins (priest):

Jimmy Tompkins (priest) was a Roman Catholic priest who founded the Antigonish Movement, a progressive effort that aimed to improve economic conditions for the fishing and mining communities of northern and eastern Nova Scotia, Canada. Born in Margaree Forks, Nova Scotia, on September 7, 1870, Tompkins attended St. Francis Xavier University in alternate semesters while teaching Greek and Mathematics to support himself from 1888-1895.

Tompkins believed in the emancipating power of education and sought to improve economic conditions through study groups and cooperative action. He started the first regional library in Nova Scotia, as well as the first credit union and cooperative housing association in Reserve Mines, which was dubbed "Tompkinsville." Tompkins was the spiritual founder of the Antigonish Movement, which later evolved into the Extension Department (now the Coady International Center) of St. Francis Xavier University.

Tompkins was known for his passion for helping the poor and marginalized, and he often said, "It is not enough to have ideas, we have to put legs on them." He was a double-cousin of Father Moses Coady, who headed the Extension Department at St. Francis Xavier University, and worked alongside other prominent figures such as Father (Dr.) Hugh MacPherson, A.B. MacDonald, and others.

Throughout his life, Tompkins remained committed to his community and his beliefs, and his legacy continues to inspire social justice and community development initiatives to this day.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Alexander Vovin.
output:
Based on the provided documents, Alexander Vovin is a Russian-American linguist and philologist who was born in Saint Petersburg, Russia in 1961. He earned his M.A. in structural and applied linguistics from Saint Petersburg State University in 1983 and his Ph.D. in historical Japanese linguistics and premodern Japanese literature from the same university in 1987. His doctoral dissertation was on the "Hamamatsu Chūnagon Monogatari" (ca. 1056).

After completing his Ph.D., Vovin served as a Junior Researcher at the St. Petersburg Institute of Oriental Studies (1987-1990). He then became Assistant Professor of Japanese at the University of Michigan (1990-1994), Miami University (1994-1995), and Assistant and Associate Professor at the University of Hawai'i (1995-2003). He became a full professor at the University of Hawai'i in 2003 and continued working there until 2014.

Vovin has also held visiting positions at various institutions, including the International Research Center for Japanese Studies in Kyoto (2001-2002, 2008), the Ruhr University Bochum in Germany (2008-2009), and the National Institute for Japanese Language and Linguistics in Tokyo, Japan (in May-August 2012).

Vovin's research specializes in Japanese historical linguistics, with an emphasis on the study of the language's grammar, syntax, and vocabulary. He is widely recognized as an expert in the field and has published numerous articles and books on Japanese linguistics.

Krystyna Szczepańska is a Polish stage and costume designer born on August 18, 1950, in Kraków. Her parents, Piotr Szczepański and Stanisława née Żółtańska, were both members of the Home Army and came from Berezhany. Krystyna has an elder sister named Alicja who is a lawyer like their father. She was married to director Andrzej Maj and designed sets and costumes for his performances. Krystyna has two daughters, Magdalena and Elizabeth, who are also involved in the arts. Magdalena is a costume and set designer active in the advertising industry and emigrated to Vancouver, while Elizabeth is a set designer.

Krystyna's professional career as a stage and costume designer began in the 1970s, and she has since worked on numerous productions, including sets and costumes for theater and film. She has also designed interiors and decorations for various events and competitions. Krystyna's work has been recognized and awarded in various competitions, including the 2004 European Combined Events Cup in Hengelo, Netherlands, where she won a silver medal.

In addition to her work as a designer, Krystyna is also a retired athlete, having competed in the heptathlon at the 2004 Olympics in Athens. She trained under the tutelage of head coach Jerzy Skucha for the national team and represented Poland in the sport.

Overall, Krystyna Szczepańska is a talented and accomplished artist with a diverse background in both design and athletics. Her work has made a significant impact in the arts and sports communities in Poland and beyond.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Jeffrey Viggiano.
output:

Jeffrey Donald "Jeff" Viggiano was born on July 24, 1984, in the United States. He is an American-born Italian professional basketball player. Viggiano played high school basketball at Suffield High School in West Suffield, Connecticut, where he won the 2000 Gatorade Player of the Year in the state of Connecticut and the State Championship alongside teammate Dan Presser.

After high school, Viggiano played four seasons of college basketball at the University of Massachusetts Amherst with the UMass Minutemen. In 2008, he was signed by the Italian LegADue team Nuova Pallacanestro Pavia, where he averaged 14.1 points and 4.2 rebounds per game and gained the call of powerhouse Armani Jeans Milano.

Viggiano has played professionally in several countries, including Sweden and Hungary with Norrköping Dolphins and Soproni Sördögök KC. He has also played for several Italian teams, including Angelico Biella, Benetton Treviso, Enel Brindisi, and Umana Reyer Venezia.

In 2014, Viggiano signed with Montepaschi Siena for the 2013–14 season, and in 2015, he re-signed with Umana Reyer Venezia for the 2014–15 season. As of 2016, Viggiano is still playing for Umana Reyer Venezia in the Lega Basket Serie A.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Maggie Cogan.
output:
Based on the provided documents, here is a brief bio of Maggie Cogan:

Maggie Cogan was born and raised in a town near New York City. She became a minor celebrity in the early 1960s when she became the first female horse and carriage driver in Central Park, working for the Plaza Hotel. Her career took off when she appeared in a 1967 Universal newsreel with her horse and carriage, and later appeared on the quiz show What's My Line? in 1968. However, she left her career briefly in the 1960s and resumed it in 1970, befriending Lisa Ryan, the daughter of actor Robert Ryan, who had also become a horse-and-carriage driver.

Cogan had two unsuccessful marriages and gave birth to two sons, but she eventually lost custody of them due to her mental health issues. In 1977, while living with Ryan, Cogan began to show signs of mental illness and was eventually committed to a mental hospital by her parents. After leaving her career for good, she became homeless and lived in Central Park for several years.

Director Michel Negroponte discovered Cogan living in Central Park and made the documentary film Jupiter's Wife about her life. Despite the challenges she faced, Cogan remained determined and independent throughout her life, reflecting the resilience and determination of a true New Yorker.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Albert Outler.
output:
Based on the provided documents, here is a bio of Albert Outler:

Albert Outler was a 20th-century American Methodist theologian and philosopher, born on November 17, 1908, in Georgia. He is widely regarded as one of the most important Wesley scholars in the history of the church and the first real United Methodist theologian. Outler was an ordained Methodist elder who served in several appointments and graduated from Wofford College before earning his Doctor of Philosophy degree from Yale University. He taught at both Yale and Duke University before beginning a long tenure at Southern Methodist University in Texas.

Outler was a delegate to the Consultation on Church Union, served on the Faith & Order board of the World Council of Churches, and was an official observer at the Second Vatican Council. He is credited with recognizing John Wesley's method for theologizing, which he referred to as the Wesleyan Quadrilateral: scripture, church tradition, reason, and personal experience. This understanding of Wesleyan theology is prevalent throughout Methodism, particularly in the United Methodist Church.

Outler was a key figure in organizing the theological work of the United Methodist Church after its formation in 1968. He wrote and edited a great many works, many of which have been collected in the "Albert Outler Library" series by Bristol House publishers. Outler's work has proven influential to those in the paleo-orthodox movement and contemporary evangelicalism, notably Thomas C. Oden.

Outler passed away on September 1, 1989, but his legacy continues to be felt in the world of Methodist theology and beyond. His contributions to the field of theology have been widely recognized, and he is widely regarded as one of the most important theologians of the 20th century.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Meg Thalken.
output:
Based on the provided documents, here is a brief bio of Meg Thalken:

Meg Thalken is an American intermedia artist known for her photographic explorations of loss. Born in Nebraska in 1952, Thalken received her BA in Psychology from Barat College in 1974 and her MFA in Photography at Yale University in 1988. During her time at Yale, Thalken was awarded several grants and fellowships, including the Yale Scholarship, Artist Support Grant, and the Alice Kimball English Traveling Fellowship.

In 1995, Thalken completed an Artist Residency Fellowship at Georgia State University, where she has lived and worked since 1990. She has received numerous individual artist research grants from various organizations, including the Welch School of Art and Design and the College of Arts and Sciences of Georgia State University, the Georgia Council for the Arts, the Dekalb Council for the Arts, the Board of Regents of the University System of Georgia, and the Hartsfield Jackson Airport Art Program.

Thalken's work has received honors from several organizations, including the Atlanta Photography Gallery, the Alice and William Jenkins Gallery, Georgia Commission on Women, Professional Women Photographers, New York Center for Photographic Art International, American Art Today: Figures and ArtsATL (Critics Memorable Art of at The Hambidge Center in Rabun Gap, Georgia).

Thalken's influences lie beyond the realm of photography, and she is inspired by readings in philosophy, anthropology, fiction, poetry, and critical writings. Some of her influences include Susan Sontag, Rachel Poliquin, C. K. Williams, Roland Barthes, Guillermo Bonfil Batalla, and Octavio Paz.

Thalken is currently an Associate Professor of Photography at the Ernest G. Welch School of Art and Design at Georgia State University, where she has taught since 1990. Throughout her career, Thalken has been recognized for her ability to carefully convey subject matter that engages the viewer perceptually, emotionally, viscerally, and intellectually.

He later returned to Puerto Rico in 1990 and produced twenty-two works over the course of a year, including "Ruth Fernandez in 1991."

Torres is not related to the Colombian professional road racing cyclist Rigoberto Urán, who was born in 1987.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Shane Fontayne.
output:
Shane Fontayne is an English rock guitarist who has been active in the music industry since the 1970s. Born on April 29, 1954, in London, England, he is known for his work with a variety of artists, including Bruce Springsteen, Ian Hunter, Van Zant, John Waite, Chris Botti, Joe Cocker, Johnny Hallyday, Marc Cohn, Randy VanWarmer, Graham Nash, and Mick Ronson.

Fontayne's career began in the 1970s, when he was associated with the English psychedelic band Byzantium. He was also a member of the precursor band Ora. In the 1990s, he played lead electric guitar for Ann and Nancy Wilson's version of "Stairway to Heaven" at the Kennedy Center Honors ceremony, with Jason Bonham taking his father's position on drums.

Fontayne has been married to actress Mackenzie Phillips from 1986 to 2000 and has a son with her, also named Shane, born in 1987. His older brother Peter is a well-known music critic in Japan.

Some of Fontayne's notable work includes his collaboration with Steve Forbert on the 1980 album "Little Stevie Orbit," his work with Maria McKee on her 1989 album, and his guitar work for Joe Cocker on the 2004 album "Heart & Soul." He has also been the guitarist for French rocker Johnny Hallyday on his 1995 tour "Lorada tour" and 1996 concert in Las Vegas.

In addition, Fontayne has been Marc Cohn's touring guitarist since 1998 and has recently worked with Crosby, Stills & Nash and Graham Nash (solo) on tour, as well as producing Nash's 2016 album "This Path Tonight."

output:
Based on the information provided in the documents, here is a bio of Michael H. Schneider Sr.:

Michael H. Schneider Sr. was born in San Antonio, Texas in 1943. He received an Associate of Arts degree from Lon Morris College in 1963, a Bachelor of Science degree from Stephen F. Austin State University in 1965, and a Juris Doctor from the University of Houston Law Center in 1970.

After graduating from law school, Schneider served as an assistant district attorney in the Harris County, Texas District Attorney's Office from 1971 to 1975. He then entered private practice in Texas from 1975 until his retirement on October 1, 2016.

Schneider is a former United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas. He was appointed to the bench in 1985 and served in that capacity until his retirement.

In addition to his legal career, Schneider has also been involved in politics. He served as a member of the Nevada Senate, representing Clark County District 11 from 1996 to 2012, when he retired due to term limits. Prior to his service in the Nevada Senate, Schneider was a member of the Nevada Assembly from 1992 through 1996.

In 2005, Schneider was sued by his 2004 Republican opponent, Danny Tarkanian, for defamation. During the campaign, Schneider had accused Tarkanian of setting up telemarketing companies that were later found to be running scams that victimized senior citizens.

Overall, Michael H. Schneider Sr. has had a distinguished career in both the legal and political fields, serving in various roles including as a district attorney, judge, and state senator.

output:
Sure! Based on the provided documents, here is a brief bio of Rachel Bilson:

Rachel Bilson is an American actress born on August 25, 1981, in Los Angeles, California. She is the daughter of Janice Stango, a sex therapist, and Danny Bilson, a writer, director, and producer. Bilson made her television debut in 2003 and landed the role of Summer Roberts on the prime-time drama series "The O.C." Her breakout role on the show led to her movie debut in "The Last Kiss" (2006) and starring in the science-fiction-action film "Jumper" (2008).

From 2011 to 2015, Bilson starred as Dr. Zoe Hart on The CW series "Hart of Dixie." She was named one of the "Hot 100 List" by Maxim magazine in 2005 and 2006, and her fashions and sense of style made her the unwitting target of the Bling Ring, who burglarized her home on several occasions. In 2011, Bilson collaborated with her personal stylist Nicole Chavez and shoe industry leader Steve Madden to launch the footwear destination, ShoeMint. In 2013, Bilson designed a shirt for Invisible Children.

Bilson dated her "The O.C." co-star Adam Brody for three years before breaking up and beginning a relationship with actor Hayden Christensen.

output: Susan Sarandon is an American actress and activist born on October 4, 1946. She has received numerous awards, including an Academy Award, a British Academy Film Award, and a Screen Actors Guild Award. She has been nominated for six Primetime Emmy Awards and nine Golden Globe Awards. Sarandon is known for her social and political activism for various causes, including her appointment as a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador in 1999 and the Action Against Hunger Humanitarian Award in 2006. She began her career in the 1970 film "Joe" and appeared in the soap opera "A World Apart" before gaining recognition for her role in the 1988 film "Bull Durham." Sarandon has been in a number of notable films, including "The Big Chill," "Thelma & Louise," and "Enchanted." She has also been in a number of high-profile relationships, including with Italian filmmaker Franco Amurri and actor Tim Robbins, with whom she has two sons. Sarandon is also a lapsed Catholic and shares liberal political views with Robbins. In 2009, she split with Robbins and began a relationship with Jonathan Bricklin, son of Malcolm Bricklin. Sarandon and Bricklin helped establish a chain of ping-pong lounges named SPiN.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Rachel Weisz.
output:
Sure, here is a bio of Rachel Weisz based on the provided documents:

Rachel Weisz is a British-American actress born on March 7, 1970, in London, England. She began her acting career in the early 1990s, appearing in television shows such as "Inspector Morse," "Scarlet and Black," and "Advocates II." She made her film debut in "Death Machine" in 1994 and went on to appear in several other films throughout the 1990s, including "Chain Reaction" in 1996 opposite Keanu Reeves and Morgan Freeman.

Weisz has also had a successful career in theater, with a stage breakthrough in the 1994 revival of Noël Coward's play "Design for Living," which earned her the London Critics' Circle Award for the most promising newcomer. She has since appeared in several other plays, including the 1999 Donmar Warehouse production alongside Alec Baldwin and Kevin Bacon.

In addition to her acting career, Weisz is a muse to fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez and has been featured on the covers of several magazines, including "insideKENT," "Vogue," and "Esquire." She was named L'Oréal's global ambassador in 2010.

Weisz became a naturalized U.S. citizen in 2011, in addition to her British citizenship. Some of her notable film roles include the 2015 film "The Lobster," which won the Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival, and "The Light Between Oceans" in 2016, opposite Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander. She also portrayed Holocaust historian Deborah Lipstadt in the film "Denial" in 2016, based on Lipstadt's book and directed by Mick Jackson.

In 2017, Weisz starred in the drama "My Cousin Rachel," based on Daphne du Maurier's novel, and co-starred in the British biographical film "The Mercy," directed by James Marsh. She also founded her own production company, LC6 Productions, which released its first feature film, "Disobedience," in 2017, starring Weisz and Rachel McAdams.

Throughout her career, Weisz has been recognized for her talent and dedication to her craft, receiving numerous awards and nominations for her performances. She continues to be a respected and influential figure in the entertainment industry, known for her versatility and passion for her work.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Sage Stallone.
output:
Sage Stallone was born on May 5, 1976, in Los Angeles, California, to Sylvester Stallone and Sasha Czack. He was the eldest son and had a younger brother, Seargeoh, and half-brothers and half-sisters, Sistine, Sophia, and Scarlet. Sage was also a nephew of actor and singer Frank Stallone and grandson of Jackie Stallone. His stepmother was model and entrepreneur Jennifer Flavin.

Sage attended Montclair College Preparatory School in Van Nuys, California, but dropped out after the scene. He then attended the University of North Carolina School of the Arts to study Filmmaking from 1994 to 1995. In 1996, he co-founded Grindhouse Releasing, a Los Angeles-based company dedicated to the restoration and preservation of exploitation films and B-movies, with film editor Bob Murawski.

Sage's acting career began when he appeared with his father in the film "Daylight" in 1996. He then acted in lesser profile films and directed his first short film, "Vic," which won the 2006 Boston Film Festival "Best New Filmmaker" award. His last projects were appearances in Vincent Gallo's last two films, "Promises Written in Water" and "The Agent."

Sage Stallone died on July 13, 2012, at the age of 36, after being found dead in his home. An autopsy and toxicology tests revealed that he died of coronary artery disease caused by atherosclerosis, with no drugs detected other than an over-the-counter pain remedy. He was reportedly engaged at the time of his death.

Sage Stallone's funeral was held on July 21 at St. Martin of Tours Catholic Church in Los Angeles, and he is interred at Westwood Village Memorial Park Cemetery. Despite his untimely death, Sage Stallone's legacy as a filmmaker and actor continues to be remembered and celebrated by fans of his work and the film industry as a whole.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Alfred Hitchcock.
output:
Alfred Hitchcock was a renowned English film director, producer, and screenwriter who is widely regarded as one of the most influential and innovative filmmakers in the history of cinema. Born in London in 1928, Hitchcock was the only child of film director Alfred Hitchcock and film editor Alma Reville. He began his career in the film industry in the 1920s, working as a title designer and assistant director before eventually becoming a director in his own right.

Hitchcock's directorial style was characterized by his use of suspense, intricate plots, and memorable characters. He was known for his meticulous attention to detail and his ability to create a sense of tension and unease in his audience. Some of his most famous films include "Psycho" (1960), "Vertigo" (1958), "Rear Window" (1954), and "North by Northwest" (1959).

In addition to his work in film, Hitchcock was also known for his distinctive personality and his love of publicity. He was a frequent guest on television shows and was known for his witty and charming persona. He was also a collector of art and antiques, and his home in Los Angeles was filled with his extensive collection.

Hitchcock was married to Alma Reville, a film editor and scriptwriter, for over 40 years until his death in 1980. He had one child, Pat Hitchcock, who also pursued a career in acting and production.

Throughout his career, Hitchcock received numerous awards and accolades, including the Academy Award for Best Director for "Psycho" in 1960. He was also appointed a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (KBE) in 1980 for his contributions to the film industry.

Hitchcock's legacy continues to be celebrated today, with many filmmakers citing him as an influence on their own work. He remains one of the most beloved and respected figures in the history of cinema, and his films continue to be enjoyed by audiences around the world.

output:
Based on the provided documents, here is a brief bio of Bobby Fischer:

Bobby Fischer was born Robert James Fischer on March 9, 1943, at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, Illinois. His birth certificate listed his father as Hans-Gerhardt Fischer, also known as Gerardo Liebscher, a German biophysicist. His mother, Regina Wender Fischer, was a US citizen.

Fischer showed great skill in chess from an early age, winning the "Game of the Century" at the age of 13 and becoming the US Chess Champion at the age of 14. At 15, he became both the youngest grandmaster (GM) up to that time and the youngest candidate for the World Championship.

In 1963, Fischer won the US Championship with 11 wins in 11 games organized by the Brooklyn YMCA Chess and Checker Club, and in a correspondence chess tournament organized by "Chess Review". He went on to make numerous lasting contributions to chess, including patenting a modified chess timing system that added a time increment after each move, which is now a standard practice in top tournament and match play.

Fischer also invented Fischerandom, a new variant of chess known today as "Chess960". He was the eleventh World Chess Champion and many consider him to be the greatest chess player of all time. Fischer died on January 17, 2008, at the age of 64, after living in Iceland until his death.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Chris Cuomo.
output:
Chris Cuomo is an American television journalist who was born on August 9, 1970, in the New York City borough of Queens. He currently works at CNN, where he presents "Cuomo Prime Time," a regular weeknight show. Cuomo has previously worked as the ABC News chief law and justice correspondent and co-anchor of "20/20." Before his current show, he was one of two co-anchors of the weekday edition of "New Day," a three-hour morning news show.

Cuomo is the son of Matilda (Raffa) and Mario Cuomo, the former Governor of New York. His father was a prominent figure in New York politics, and Cuomo has spoken fondly of his relationship with his father. In a statement, U.S. Congressman Peter King described Mario Cuomo as a "giant of New York government and politics," and praised his understanding and appreciation of the political process.

Cuomo has been recognized for his journalism career, including being picked as one of "People" magazine's 50 Most Beautiful People in 1997. His daughter Maria is married to Kenneth Cole, a well-known New York fashion designer, and is Chair of the Board of HELP USA, a charitable foundation.

Throughout his career, Cuomo has covered a wide range of news topics, including politics, law, and social issues. He has been praised for his in-depth reporting and thoughtful analysis, and has earned a reputation as a respected and knowledgeable journalist.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Amelia Earhart.
output:
Amelia Earhart was born on July 24, 1897, and disappeared on July 2, 1937, while attempting to fly around the world. She was an American aviation pioneer and author, known for being the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Earhart received the United States Distinguished Flying Cross for this accomplishment and set many other records, wrote best-selling books about her flying experiences, and was instrumental in the formation of The Ninety-Nines, an organization for female pilots.

In addition to her aviation accomplishments, Earhart was a successful writer and served as aviation editor for "Cosmopolitan" magazine from 1928 to 1930. She wrote magazine articles, newspaper columns, essays, and published two books based on her experiences as a flyer during her lifetime. Earhart was also a visiting faculty member at Purdue University, serving as an advisor to aeronautical engineering and a career counselor to women students.

Earhart's life has been the subject of much fascination and creative expression, including a film titled "Amelia" (2009) starring Hilary Swank as Earhart and Christopher Eccleston as her navigator, Fred Noonan. The film follows the final leg of their around-the-world flight and provides a glimpse into Earhart's life and personality.

Overall, Amelia Earhart was a groundbreaking aviator and writer who made significant contributions to the field of aviation and inspired countless people with her courage, determination, and passion for flying.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Dr. Dre.
output:
Dr. Dre, born Andre Brown on December 5, 1963, is an American radio personality and former MTV VJ. In the early 1980s, he was a DJ at WBAU, the radio station of Adelphi University in Garden City, New York, where he formed the "Concept Crew" with three other DJs at the station. They began creating their own music and in 1986, they renamed themselves Original Concept, a hip-hop group that released one album on Def Jam Recordings in 1988, "Straight from the Basement of Kooley High." Dr. Dre's best-known track from the album was "Pump that Bass."

Dr. Dre has also had a successful career in the music industry as a rapper, music producer, and entrepreneur. He co-hosted Yo! MTV Raps with Ed Lover from 1989 to 1995 and guest appeared on msnbc's The Beat with Ari Melber in 2018. In 2007, Ronin Ro released "Dr. Dre: The Biography," a book that covers the early days of Dr. Dre's career and his time with the World Class Wreckin' Cru, N.W.A, and Ruthless, the release of The Chronic and his time at Death Row, and the formation of his record label Aftermath, and the production work with artists such as Eminem, Snoop Dogg, 50 Cent, The Game (rapper), etc., to present. A positive review of the book was written by Mike Tribby for Booklist.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Quincy Jones.
output:
Sure, here is a bio of Quincy Jones based on the provided documents:

Quincy Jones is an American record producer, musician, composer, and film producer who was born on March 14, 1933, in Chicago, Illinois. He is also known as "Q." Jones' career spans six decades in the entertainment industry, during which he has been nominated for a record 79 Grammy Awards and has won 27 Grammys, including a Grammy Legend Award in 1992.

Jones grew up in Chicago and attended the Berklee College of Music. He began his career as a jazz arranger and conductor in the 1950s before moving on to work in pop music and film scores. In 1969, Jones and his songwriting partner Bob Russell became the first African Americans to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Song for their work on the film "The Wiz."

In 2018, a documentary film about Jones' life, titled "Quincy," was released on Netflix. The film was co-written and co-directed by Jones' daughter Rashida Jones and Alan Hicks, and produced by Paula DuPré Pesmen. The documentary focuses on Jones' extraordinary life and accomplishments in the music and film industry, including his work with legendary artists such as Michael Jackson, Frank Sinatra, and Ray Charles.

Jones has had a long and successful career in the entertainment industry, working with a wide range of artists and producing numerous hit albums and films. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential and innovative producers of his generation, and his contributions to the music and film industries have been recognized with numerous awards and accolades.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of George Washington.
output:
George Washington (February 22, 1732 – December 14, 1799) was the first President of the United States, serving from 1789 to 1797. He played a central role in the American Revolution, commanding the Continental Army to victory against the British Empire from 1775 to 1783. Washington's character and leadership were instrumental in shaping the United States into the country it is today.

Biographer Mason Weems was the first to publish a detailed account of Washington's life in 1800, followed by Douglas Southall Freeman and David Hackett Fischer, among others. These writers emphasized Washington's integrity, self-discipline, courage, honesty, and decency, as well as his commitment to civic virtue and republicanism.

Washington's legacy extends beyond his political achievements. He is often referred to as the "Father of his Country," and his image is ubiquitous in American culture. His commitment to private life and his example of piety, justice, humanity, temperance, and sincerity have made him an iconic figure in American history.

Congressman Henry "Light Horse Harry" Lee, a Revolutionary War comrade and father of the American Civil War general Robert E. Lee, famously eulogized Washington as "First in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen." Lee's words capture the esteem in which Washington was held by his contemporaries and the American people at large.

In summary, George Washington was a towering figure in American history, known for his leadership, character, and commitment to civic virtue. His legacy continues to inspire and shape the United States to this day.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Valerie Harper.
output:
Valerie Harper is an American actress born on August 22, 1939, in Suffern, New York. She is best known for her roles as Rhoda Morgenstern in "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and its spin-off, "Rhoda," and as Valerie Hogan in the sitcom "Valerie." Harper has won four Primetime Emmy Awards and has been nominated for numerous other awards, including eight Emmy Awards and six Golden Globe Awards.

In addition to her television work, Harper has also had notable film roles, including "Freebie and the Bean" (1974) and "Chapter Two" (1979), both of which earned her Golden Globe Award nominations. She has also appeared in several Broadway productions, including "Looped" in 2010, for which she was nominated for a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play.

Harper was born to Iva Mildred (née McConnell) and Howard Donald Harper. She is the middle child of three siblings, with an older sister, Leah, and a younger brother, Merrill (who later took the name "Don"). Harper started her career as a dancer on Broadway, making her debut in the musical "Take Me Along" in 1959.

Throughout her career, Harper has been recognized for her talent and dedication to her craft, earning her numerous awards and nominations. She continues to work in the entertainment industry, both on stage and screen, and is widely regarded as one of the most talented and versatile actresses of her generation.
